channel.title: NYT > U.S. News

item.title: Trump Raises Middle Finger at Heckler in Michigan Ford Factory Tour
item.description: A White House spokesman said the president “gave an appropriate and unambiguous response.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump touring a Ford factory in Dearborn, Mich., on Tuesday.

item.title: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey, Who Cussed Out ICE, Is No Stranger to Crisis
item.description: Mayor Jacob Frey, a Democrat, has clashed with his party’s activist wing. His response to ICE has won him new respect at home and new foes in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Jacob Frey in his office at City Hall in Minneapolis.

item.title: Senator Says Prosecutors Are Investigating Her After Video About Illegal Orders
item.description: It is unclear what possible crime might involve Senator Elissa Slotkin, a Democrat, who has warned in dire terms about the dissolution of American democracy.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Elissa Slotkin of Michigan, a former C.I.A. officer, organized a video with five other Democratic lawmakers in which they urged military service members to resist illegal orders.

item.title: ICE Arrested Dozens of Refugees in Minnesota and Sent Them to Texas, Lawyers Say
item.description: The refugees, many of them from Somalia, had passed security screenings before coming to the United States. The Trump administration has vowed to “re-examine thousands of refugee cases.”
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol agents clashed with community members after federal immigration officers crashed into a vehicle in south Minneapolis to ask about the driver’s immigration status on Monday.

item.title: Louisiana Indicts a California Doctor Over Abortion Pills
item.description: The indictment, followed by a request to extradite the doctor from California, is an escalation of Louisiana’s efforts to counter states that support providing abortions.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Charlie Neibergall/Associated Press
item.media:description: Conservative leaders opposed to abortion have sought various ways to limit access to the abortion pills mifepristone and misoprostol, which Louisiana classified as dangerous controlled substances in 2024.

item.title: 2028 Los Angeles Olympics: How to Register for Tickets
item.description: Starting Wednesday, prospective buyers can enter a lottery to get a chance to purchase the first tickets in April. Prices will start at $28.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: 2028 will be the third time Los Angeles hosts the Summer Games, after 1932 and 1984.

item.title: Analysis: Trump Supports Protesters in Iran, but Not in Minneapolis
item.description: The split-screen television images of mass demonstrations in Minneapolis and Tehran have highlighted the president’s disparate views of democracy and popular dissent.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: The television images of mass protests in the streets of Minneapolis and Tehran in recent days have invariably highlighted the complications and contradictions of Donald J. Trump’s presidency.

item.title: Paraglider Survives 500-Foot Crash Into Ocean Off Florida, Rescuers Say
item.description: A bystander captured the misadventure in a video that drew widespread attention online. Lifeguards and a snorkeler helped rescue the man.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Claudette Colvin, Who Refused to Give Her Bus Seat to a White Woman, Dies at 86
item.description: Her defiance of Jim Crow laws in 1955 made her a star witness in a landmark segregation suit, but her act was overshadowed months later when Rosa Parks made history with a similar stand.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Dudley M. Brooks/The The Washington Post, via Roseboro Holdings and The Colvin Family Legacy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Claudette Colvin in 1998. When she was ordered to move to the back of a bus in 1955, she refused: “History had me glued to the seat,” she said.

item.title: Trump nominates a company chief and Republican donor, David MacNeil, to the F.T.C.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Sara Stathas/Alamy
item.media:description: David MacNeil, a Republican political donor, is the founder and chief executive of WeatherTech, an Illinois company that manufacturers products including floor mats for cars and homes.

item.title: In Secret Testimony, Republicans Derided Trump’s Stolen Election Claims
item.description: The testimony, part of the derailed Georgia election interference case, makes clear how dismissive some senior Republicans were of claims of widespread fraud in the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
item.category: Georgia Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election)
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Transcripts of secret grand jury testimony indicate that President Trump’s efforts to overturn his defeat in the 2020 presidential election exasperated and alarmed a number of senior Republicans.

item.title: Justice Dept. Memo Said Trump Could Send Troops Into Venezuela Unilaterally
item.description: The memo offers a detailed look into the administration’s legal justification for the military incursion into Venezuelan territory in early January.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has started showing a Justice Department memo to members of Congress that broadly covers whether President Trump needed congressional authorization to direct the recent military operation in Venezuela.

item.title: Timothy Busfield, Actor and Director, Turns Himself In for Child Sex Abuse Charges
item.description: He was booked on Tuesday, the Albuquerque police said. He is accused of inappropriately touching two boys on the set of a drama series.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Steven Ferdman/Getty Images
item.media:description: Timothy Busfield at an event in New York in 2020.

item.title: In a Risky Gambit, Trump Tries Brute Force to Lower Prices
item.description: To assuage cost-weary voters and combat inflation, the president has resorted to a mix of threats and punishments, targeting companies and policymakers alike.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: There is seemingly no lever that President Trump appears unwilling to pull, as he looks to ease the economic strains on voters now anxious about the state of the country.

item.title: Blowback Builds Over Criminal Investigation of Powell
item.description: Trump allies fear that the inquiry into the Fed chair could complicate the process of replacing him this year.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Colby Smith, Glenn Thrush and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Global economic leaders have expressed concern about the credibility of the world’s most important economic institution after the Justice Department’s announcement of an investigation into the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell.

item.title: Trump Loyalist Asserts She Can Keep U.S. Attorney Title
item.description: In an aggressively worded filing, Lindsey Halligan accused a judge of having a fundamental misunderstanding of the order that determined she had been unlawfully appointed.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jacquelyn Martin/Associated Press
item.media:description: The dispute over Lindsey Halligan’s position comes amid persistent turmoil in the Eastern District of Virginia, a critical prosecutorial outpost known for its handling of terrorism and national security cases.

item.title: How John Kennedy, a G.O.P. Senator, Became a Best-Selling Book Author
item.description: Senator John Kennedy, a garrulous rank-and-file Republican from Louisiana, has struck a nerve with a new book that provides an insider account of Congress and its dysfunction.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator John Kennedy’s book on Washington has sold close to half a million copies.

item.title: Videos Show Increasingly Aggressive Federal Crackdown in Minneapolis
item.description: Arrests and aggressive tactics by ICE and the Border Patrol, many seen on viral videos, have intensified the frustration and fear among residents.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Jazmine Ulloa

item.title: Trump Administration Will End Deportation Protections for Somalis
item.description: The temporary protections, which are meant to help migrants who cannot safely return to their countries, are expected to expire for Somalis on March 17.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women leaving a mosque in Bloomington, Minn. Minnesota has the largest Somali population in the United States.

item.title: A.D.F., a Christian conservative legal organization, is assisting Idaho and West Virginia.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Andrew Harnik/Associated Press
item.media:description: Kristen Waggoner, a lawyer for the Alliance Defending Freedom, outside the Supreme Court in 2022.

item.title: Justice Kavanaugh May Bring a Coach’s Perspective to the Case
item.description: The justice, a sports buff, has coached girls’ basketball teams for many years and has often reflected on the role such mentoring can play.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, center, posed with students he coached in 2018.

item.title: Before White House Meeting, Greenland’s Leader Says Island Would Choose Denmark Over U.S.
item.description: Greenland’s leader said that, if given the choice between the United States and Denmark, the Greenlanders would rather stick with the Danes.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Tom Little/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen of Greenland, left, and Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark held a joint news conference in Copenhagen on Tuesday.

item.title: Organizing bodies have grappled with gender issues, pleasing few.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Imane Khelif, a boxer from Algeria who won the women’s gold medal at the 2024 Olympics in Paris. World Boxing, the sport’s international federation, suspended Ms. Khelif from boxing against women until she submitted to gender testing.

item.title: Appeals courts have split over bathroom bans for transgender youths.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon
item.media:credit: Mark Ralston/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Makeshift signs on a gender neutral bathroom in a California high school in 2016.

item.title: Six Prosecutors Quit Over DOJ Push to Investigate Renee Good’s Widow
item.description: Joseph H. Thompson, a career federal prosecutor who was the acting U.S. attorney for Minnesota last year, was among those who resigned as the Justice Department sought to examine the woman’s supposed ties to activist groups.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Ben Brewer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph H. Thompson, a federal prosecutor, has led the prosecution of fraud in social services programs in Minnesota.

item.title: Number of Trans Athletes Affected by Bans Is Low, but the Debate Is Broad
item.description: The people who support barring trans girls from girls’ sports say the debate affects not just transgender athletes but whole teams and sports.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Pepper-Jackson, a transgender athlete in West Virginia, holds a discus.

item.title: Researchers Still Debating Whether Trans Athletes Have an Edge
item.description: The issue is complex: Individual sports rely on different physical and physiological attributes, and no two gender transitions are identical.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the center of the Supreme Court debate is whether trans women retain an athletic advantage once they start taking drugs to transition.

item.title: Hints Suggest How 2 Key Justices May View Trans Athletes in Women’s Sports
item.description: There are some indications from questions at arguments and past writing how Justices Amy Coney Barrett and Brett Kavanaugh view the issue before the court.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Amy Coney Barett.

item.title: 2 Students Behind Challenges to Trans Athlete Laws
item.description: One sued to join her middle school girls’ cross-country team in West Virginia and the other to join the women’s track and cross-country teams at her university in Idaho.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Pepper-Jackson sued her state in 2021 to join her middle school girls’ cross-country team.

item.title: 27 States Restrict Trans Participation in School Sports
item.description: Over the past six years, more than two dozen state legislatures have enacted laws on transgender athletes. Idaho, whose statute is being challenged before the Supreme Court, was the first in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Idaho was the first of 27 states that have enacted laws in rapid succession restricting transgender athletes’s participation in school sports.

item.title: Here are the lawyers arguing the cases.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court in Washington.

item.title: Bill and Hillary Clinton Refuse to Testify in Epstein Inquiry
item.description: The couple escalated their battle with Representative James R. Comer, the chairman of the Oversight Committee, who said he would move to hold them in contempt of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative James R. Comer has repeatedly threatened to hold Bill and Hillary Clinton in contempt if they failed to appear for live depositions behind closed doors.

item.title: Barring transgender women from women’s sports has been a prominent goal for Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the signing of an executive order barring transgender women from competing in women’s sports at federally funded educational institutions.

item.title: Here’s How the Supreme Court Ruled in Cases Involving Transgender Rights
item.description: Among them: The justices have allowed the administration to stop issuing passports with gender identity markings selected by applicants.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Supreme Court, opposing groups on transgender care rallied in 2024.

item.title: Supreme Court’s Ruling on Trans Athletes Could Apply to 2 or Many
item.description: The parties disagree about whether the court’s ruling should be categorical or turn on the challengers’ individual circumstances.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the help of the American Civil Liberties Union and Lambda Legal, Becky Pepper-Jackson and her mother, Heather Jackson, filed a lawsuit, saying a ban of her participation in high school sports violated Title IX protections against sex discrimination in schools and the 14th Amendment’s equal protection guarantee.

item.title: Here’s the latest on the argument.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

item.title: Why This 15-Year-Old’s Case Is at the Supreme Court
item.description: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court will hear two cases involving transgender athletes and their participation in women’s sports. One of the plaintiffs, the 15-year-old track athlete Becky Pepper-Jackson, spoke to the reporter Ann E. Marimow ahead of the hearing.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow, Sutton Raphael, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Christina Shaman, Whitney Shefte and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Ask The Morning: ICE and Deportations
item.description: Have questions about the Trump administration’s deportation efforts? We will try to find answers.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning

item.title: Supreme Court Appears Inclined to Allow States to Bar Transgender Athletes
item.description: The outcome of a pair of cases on Tuesday could affect laws in 27 states that prohibit transgender girls from joining girls’ and women’s sports teams.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Pepper-Jackson, who sued to join her middle school’s girls’ cross-country team when she was 11, asserted that her state’s statute violates Title IX.

item.title: Facing Political Pressure, Trump Seeks Answer to Rising Housing Costs
item.description: White House officials have explored a vast array of ideas as the president looks to unfurl a housing affordability plan at an economic conference this month.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:credit: Mike Belleme for The New York Times
item.media:description: Home prices have soared in recent years, climbing nearly 55 percent from the first quarter of 2020 to the third quarter of 2025.

item.title: The House Republican Majority Is Down to Almost Nothing
item.description: Unexpected vacancies have whittled the G.O.P.’s edge to just a couple of votes, leaving Speaker Mike Johnson with almost no margin for leading the chamber.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu and Annie Karni

item.title: The Quest to ‘Make America Fertile Again’ Stalls Under Trump
item.description: Administration officials have been urging Americans to get married and procreate, but some conservatives are frustrated by a lack of action.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kitchener
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Republican lawmakers and conservative policy groups have pushed unsuccessfully to significantly expand tax credits for families.

item.title: What High School Seniors Wrote in Their College Admissions Essays
item.description: Some students are still mentioning their race or immigrant status as the Trump administration cracks down on diversity efforts. But many are avoiding sensitive aspects of their identity.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Mokam
item.media:credit: KT Kanazawich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zhi McMillan, a senior from Virginia, highlighted in his essay an experience at a historical burial ground for African Americans.
